column3: Gwendolyn Brooks

<font color='darkgreen'>--I wonder how many others have regarded this connection? And no, James Baldwin did not start the fire. He foretold it's coming. He was a pre-reporter. He was a prophet, his friends</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>enjoy calling him Jimmy. (Remember that he was alive when I wrote this). And that is easy to understand.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>The man is love personified. He has a sweet, softly loving, endearing smile. He has a voice that can range from eerie, effortless menace -- menace educational and creative -- to this low, cradling,</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>insinuating, and involving love.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>This love is at once both father and son to a massive concern. A concern for his own people, surely. But for the cleansing the extension of all the world's categories, no less surely, since he knows</font>
surely that the fortunes of these over here affect inevitably, the fortunes of those over there.

<font color='darkgreen'>Essayist, novelist, poet, playwright, new French Legion of Honor medalist (and he was at that time), human being, being human! And I said James Baldwin, and the crowd went wild! Angela Jackson is an</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>experimenter. She respects many people, but she long ago decided not to sound like them.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>So she ended up sounding like Angela Jackson. So many little twists and turns in her work. Rarely are you prepared for them. So many satisfying perceptions of actuals, we recognize remember, or are</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>now ready to learn. Such impudent portraits of people. People she paints or invents. Such combos of colloquial and obscure, bound to confound and delight. And I say: well, here is something different</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>for your dinner.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>I hope there are some award givers in the audience here. You remember these names. Michael Harper believes that delight is possible for the reader, as well as the creator of poetry. Believes that the</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>reader, when permitted, participates in the act of creation, extending often this wonder of making within the limits, of course, of individual experience and fantasy.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Well, Michael Harper is right there to cooperate with this need of the reader. Further, in much of his poetry, he has defied the Orthodox, the alien, the prescribed, the timid, and the dim. His work</font>
with language is various and respectful. Here is the author of the classic A Mother Speaks: The Algiers Motel Incident, Detroit, and of other shapely and persuasive excellences.

<font color='darkgreen'>And he did read that poem yesterday. I was just sitting there, daring him to omit it, as he often does. Because I think that's my favorite among the poems that he has written. And I'm so glad that I</font>
didn't have to shout up from the audience for Rita to read The Island Women of Paris, which among all of her many rich poems is my favorite. Thank you.

<font color='darkgreen'>Now let's see now. I have -- I had six Chicano poets: Sandra Cisneros, Luis Omar Salinas, Alberto Ríos, and Lorna Dee Cervantes. But I'm not going to read those notes. I wanted to, but we don't have</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>that much time.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Because I do want you to hear some of my poetry. There are people here, I'm sure, who have never heard a single one of my poems. Before I come to Haki and Sonia, I can't resist reading this little</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>squib that introduced Louis Simpson. Do many of you know Louis Simpson?</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>I started out by saying: Something wicked, this way comes. Here comes Louis Simpson -- He was sitting there getting redder and redder as he listened to this -- Here comes Louis Simpson, communicator</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>of intricate darkness of feeling and instinct. So says Donald Hall. Firey defender of Gary Snyder, accused universally. Certain circles cite him as coldly capable of exhaustive wickedness.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Not I, I didn't say so. For almost two decades, he has been soundly spanked for opining that if blacks write only about Blackness, they are inadequate. That they are, in fact, non-poets.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>You decide for yourselves whether or not that's wicked. But I myself found out how dangerous Simpson the savior can be. I remember with delight that years ago, at Stony Brook, I was having a lovely</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>peaceful lunch with this poet and teacher, in a cheerfully sunny room, when I made the quotes, "mistake", end quotes, of saying that there were no Grrrreat (capital G and lots of Rs), Grrrreat poets,</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>living and writing today.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>That was some years ago. What we -- that we know of, that is, because of course there is always some unknown genius, toiling at the top of a tenement, about to burst full-bodied and beautiful and</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>persuasive upon the populace. "No great poets? Gary Snyder!", screamed Louis.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>He turned red -- he can do that -- and lifting himself to hellish height in his chair, bit my head off. And I said in parentheses, that is why I have no head. Oh well. Wicked or not, Lewis Simpson,</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>poet of careful subjectivity, poet of luminous requiring lyricism, is here tonight. (And I wave to you).   [[00:07:50 | 00:07:52 | Laughter]] [[00:08:11 | 00:08:17 |Applause]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Haki Madhubuti and Sonia Sanchez, they came together. The introducing is longer tonight because I have a double introduction, and one that seeks to put some things in place. Both these poets at times</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>have been called racists.</font>
I define racism as prejudice with oppression. That is, you are permitted to detest green eyes. That's all right. That's personal. What you are not permitted to do is kill every green eyed
<font color='darkgreen'>individual you encounter. That's not all right. That's oppression. These two people are not killers.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>They are lovers of humanity: of what is human. They are interpreters and protectors of Blackness. They are subscribers to what is beautiful in the world. They will offer you representative Black</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>poetry. My saying that does not assault our mutual understanding that there are respectable Black uniquities.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>However, today many Black poets are flopping off in worrisome directions. Many of them do not know what to do or be. Many of them want above all things not to be Black. Black people who want above all</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>things not to be Black are the most pitiable and comical people in the world.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>The poets among such fight Blackness with every punch and pout in their power. Such people are very busy imitating the new moderns: those manufacturers of chopped-up journalism, dazed and dopey.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Such people have been fondled and adopted by non-spunky white poets and critics who of course have no interest in preserving and in firming the bolts, the binders of Blackness. They would like</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Blackness to disappear altogether.</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Insert: "Oh, dear!" I know history may repeat itself. Do you know -- well you'll be able to tell just when this was written, and I told you in 1985.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Do you know that precious past election story about Jesse Jackson? He was crossing a large body of water in a small boat with the Pope. It was windy. Suddenly the Pope's little cap flew off his head.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Then Jesse Jackson stepped out of the boat, walked across the water -- I can tell some of you know this story -- retrieved the cap, walked back, clapped the cap on the Pope's head.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Next morning, the newspaper streamers proclaimed: Jesse Jackson can't swim. Well ultimately, in all my non-grandeur, I may see captions announcing "When Brooks calls all white critics non-spunky".</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>[[00:12:18 | 00:12:20 | Laughter]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>However, Sonia Sanchez is an explorer. I have always thought of her as one of that quintet of Black people: herself, Mari Evans, Don L. Lee, who became Haki, Etheridge Knight, and Nikki Giovanni who</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>is here in this audience.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Who -- and she's going to read next -- who admired the impudent spirit of Baraka, and who themselves began, in '66 and '67, to turn Black poetry around. I do not mean that these people suddenly</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>spurted up in those years. They were all writing voluminously when I met them, and they were publishing too.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Dudley Randall, poet and founder of Broadside Press, courageously published, platformed them all. In the late '60s, the quintet tried to do something fresh: defining Black poetry as poetry written by</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>blacks, about blacks, to blacks. I am not accountable for any changes.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>In the late '60s that word "to" has been wickedly translated often into "for". Any poetry... is for any readers or listeners willing to investigate it. I believe all factions should be willing to</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>investigate Black poetry.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Black people, I think will be around forever. Anyone is likely to meet them suddenly. Border, boardroom, boulevard, bistro, back-alley, bar. And it behooveth the anyone to know what makes the brie</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>tick.   [[00:14:29 | 00:14:40 | Laughter and Applause]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Sonia and Haki have remained loyal to their early recreated essence. They like the word "Consistent". Sonia can be mischievous. She called me up a while ago -- remember this was in '85 -- and said,</font>
Gwen, I want your permission to use the form you used in the Anniad. In Annie Allen.

<font color='darkgreen'>I told her, in no way does Sonia Sanchez need my permission to do anything she wants to do. But Sonia, that is not my form. It's European. And that was mischievous because in those days, anything</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>European was absolutely anathema.   [[00:15:33 | 00:15:33 | Cough]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>The language of Sonia Sanchez is --skipped something. Even poets, these two are least likely to flop back into the '40s. The language of Sonia Sanchez is her own best introduction. Of course, one of</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>her serious and inclusive avowals is this: If you're going out to say something, your house must be in order, because there is so much disorder outside.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>You will experience in her product lyricism and steel. You will be aware of Sonia Sanchez as committed poet, energized woman, necessary black. Incidentally, the prize that I mentioned has already been</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>given to both Mari Evans and Sonia in a preceding year.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>About Haki, pioneer. Haki respects Sonia and she respects him, as artist and as family. Those who love and those who loathe Haki agree that he has remained actively loyal to the richness of his faith</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>in and love for Black people.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>He spanks them now and then, but only as a benevolent father would spank them aching in his awareness of how much there is to hurt them in themselves and outside themselves. Aching in his wish that</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>they maintain integrity, and a decent family loyalty. He has influenced thousands of poets: Black poets, Hispanic poets, and strangely, you may feel, Caucasian poets, who sensed a vibrance, a vigor in</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>his dealings with language which they came to admire.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Haki has said, "What writers write about tells to what extent they are involved with the real world. Writers should be questioners of the world and doers within the world. Question everything, and</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>don't be satisfied with the quick surface answers. Bad writing, containing the most revolutionary idea, is first and last bad writing. The ability to develop a style that is clear, original, and</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>communicative is what separates writers from non-writers", end quote.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Haki had, 10 years ago, a famous list of Black clichés he wanted to see in Black poetry not again. I think he would endorse that list today. Warrior, ebony, whitey, Queen of the Nile, right on -- you</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>know, I never hear that anymore -- African warrior, pig, pride, soul, universe, Cosmas, nigger, genocide, vibrations, Black is Beautiful, revolution, respect, change.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>And then I had such fun in ending that, "Here is Haki Madhubuti, pssst... African Warrior". Well okay. those are people, insufficiently sung. Who should be sung. And I leave the audience to do</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>something about that.</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Now I'm going to read you some poems, but before I do that, I want to ask Joanne how much time I have, because I'm sure we're out of kilter here.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='blueviolet'>You're fine.</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>Tell me how many minutes I have.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='blueviolet'>Fifteen.</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>I don't think I'm gonna have that, it'll spill.</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='blueviolet'>Alright. Alright.</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>Fifteen? 15 minutes?</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='blueviolet'>Yes.</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>Okay!</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Speaker Unknown: As long as you want!</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>Well no, you've got another program. You've got some more poets to listen to. But thank you. I'm going to start with a...</font>
Joanne V. Gabbin
<font color='blueviolet'>I can [inaudible].</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
<font color='darkgreen'>I'm sorry?</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Speaker Unknown: We'll give up our time for you, Gwen. Go ahead!</font>
Gwendolyn Brooks
Well I won't go much -- but yeah, that if any. Thank you though. I'm going to begin by reading a few poems to you, from Children Coming Home. That's my latest book. Came out
in '91. And it contains -- incidentally, I promised several audiences that I was going to bring out Collected Poems sometime in 1995. But I'm not.
I'm going to wait until I'm 80 to bring out a Collected Poems, hoping I shall have written some masterpieces within those years. But I'm going to bring out Report from Part Two, which

<font color='darkgreen'>will contain reports from part two, and also poetry and some essays. And, what else, and it's guaranteed -- I am guaranteeing myself that it will come out on August 15th. Because August 15th will be</font>
the 50th anniversary of my first publication. A Street in Bronzeville came out in '45.

<font color='darkgreen'>Well that sounds good, but you know, that's no compliment to me. I mean, whether you like it or not, whether you do anything or not, time passes. And one of these days little Rita is going to be</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>stumbling up these stairs -- having hoped that when she came into the auditorium she would find stairs with banisters.   [[00:22:07 | 00:22:12 | Laughter]] [[00:22:18 | 00:22:22 | Laughter]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Well I was going to tell you these are intuitions, meditations, passions, whimsies, terrors, excited pride, affirmations, rejections, and warm love. Children of the inner city. I hate that phrase. I</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>hope you do too. It sounds so demoting: "the inner city".</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Not all of these kids come home to cookies and cocoa, some come to crack cocaine. The first poem is called the -- I'm not gonna read them all, and not a one leaves its page you'll be happy to know.</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>The first one is called the Coora flower, C-o-o-r-a, and it introduces to you Tinsel Marie, who is a hip little sister. No stranger to irony.</font>
"Today I learned the coora flower/ grows high in the mountains of Itty-go-luba Bésa./ Province Meechee./ Pop. 39.// Now I am coming home./ This, at least, is Real, and what I know.// It was

<font color='darkgreen'>restful, learning nothing necessary./ School is tiny vacation. At least you can sleep./ At least you can think of love or feeling your boyfriend against you/ (which is not free from grief.)//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"But now it's Real Business./ I am Coming Home.// My mother will be screaming in an almost dirty dress./ The crack is Gone. So a Man will be in the house.// I must watch myself./ I must not dare to</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>sleep."</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Richardine inhabits this poem: "White girls are peculiar people./ They cannot keep their hands out of their hair./ Also/ they are always shaking it away from their eyes/ When it is not in their eyes./</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Sometimes when it is braided they forget --/"   [[00:24:54 | 00:24:58 | Laughter and Applause]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"And shake and shake/ and smooth what is nothing/ away from their shameless eyes.// I laugh.// My hair is short./ It is close to my head./ It is almost a crown of dots./ My head is clean and free./ I</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>do not shake my head to make/ my brains like a crazy dust."   [[00:25:34 | 00:25:42 | Applause]]</font>
Religion features Ulysses. This is an interesting little family. "At home, we pray every morning, we/ get down on our knees in a circle,/ holding hands, holding Love,/ And we sing Hallelujah.//
<font color='darkgreen'>Then we go into the World.// Daddy <u>speeds</u> to break bread with his Girl Friend./ Mommy's a Boss. and a lesbian./ (She too has a nice Girl Friend.)//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"My brothers and sisters and I come to school./ We bring knives pistols bottles, little boxes, and cans.// We talk to the man who's cool at the playground gate./ Nobody Sees us, nobody stops our</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>sin.// Our teachers feed us geography./ We spit it out in a hurry.// Now we are coming home.// At home we pray every evening, we/ get down on our knees in a circle,/ holding hands, holding Love./ And</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>we sing Hallelujiah."</font>
Would you people get tired of clapping forever? You don't have to. Merle, M-e-r-l-e, inhabits a poem called Uncle Seagram. Many of you know that there are at least many Black families, I don't
<font color='darkgreen'>know about others, who name their children after whiskies. And you've met Calvert and you've met Johnnie Walker. And this man's mother named him Seagram.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"My uncle likes me too much.// I am five and a half years old, and in kindergarten./ In kindergarten everything is clean.// My uncle is six feet tall with seven bumps on his chin./ My uncle is six</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>feet tall and he stumbles./ Stumbles because of his Wonderful Medicine/ packed in his pocket at all times.// Family is ma and pa and my uncle,/ three brothers, three sisters, and me.// Every night in</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>my house we play checkers and dominoes./ My uncle sits <u>close</u>./ There aren't any shoes or socks on his feet./"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Under the table, a big toe tickles my ankle./ Under the oil cloth his thin knee beats into mine./ And mashes. And mashes.// When we look at TV/ my uncle picks <u>me</u> to sit on his lap./ As I sit,</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>he gets hard in the middle./ I squirm, but he keeps me, and kisses my ear.// I am not even a girl.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Once, when I went to the bathroom,/ my uncle noticed, came in, shut the door,/ put his long white tongue in my ear,/ and whispered 'We're Best Friends and Family,/ and we know how to keep Secrets.'/</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>My uncle likes me too much. I am worried./ I do not like my uncle anymore."</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Those of you... If there are any white mothers in here of Black children you know this poem does not refer to you. The poem featuring Fleur, F-l-e-u-r. And it's called: <i>Our White Mother Says We Are</font>
Black But Not Very. "My brother and I are Nice People./ We are Black, but we have creamy skin./ We have hair that is naturally curly./ We wear jackets and shoes that cost lots of money./ Our lunch
<font color='darkgreen'>box was hammered in Holland./"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"We live in the biggest house on our street/ and will move Very Soon to a Special Neighborhood./ But even in this house we have shelves and shelves,/ we have cases and cases of books with fine</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>bindings./ And sometimes we even read them. Our father/ speaks six languages, our mother speaks three./"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Each of us takes at least two showers a day.// We simply cannot abide smelly children/ or children with dull hurt eyes.// My brother and I will grow up to be/ doctors or lawyers or Supreme Court</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Justices/ or perfume distributors or Wall Street wizards./ Or the ones who discover the answer-to-cancer.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"My brother and I do not have many friends, it is true.// But at Home we'll wait for High Tea./ Little scones with cinnamon butter,/ salmon croquettes with flakes of green pepper,/ little cucumber</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>sandwiches, cashews,/ sugar in cubes with our English Breakfast Tea./ Candied ginger./ And Orange juice if we want it."</font>
Puzzlement. Diego. Diego has been in school, and it's Black pride day, and little Black children are running all around hollering: I'm Black and I'm proud! "I, partly Nigerian./ I, partly

<font color='darkgreen'>Puerto Rican.// I have a Nigerian father,/ A Puerto Rican mother./ I am packed in a skin that is tan.// I, too, have a heart on fire./ I too want to be Proud./ I, too, want to be Something and Proud./</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>I want to shout "I'M A TAN!"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Well, the last selection from this book is Kojo's poem. And I want you to know I meet lots and lots of Kojos all over the country and I am so proud to be able to report that to you. This poem is</font>
called I am a Black. "According to my Teachers,/ I am now an African-American.// They call me out of my name.// BLACK is an open umbrella./ I am Black and A Black forever.//"

<font color='darkgreen'>"I am one of The Blacks.// We are Here, we are There./ We occur in Brazil, in Nigeria, Ghana,/ In Botswana, Tanzania, in Kenya,/ In Russia, Australia, in Haiti. Soweto,/ In Grenada, in Cuba, in</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Panama, Libya,/ in England and Italy, France.// We are graces in any places./ I am Black and A Black/ forever.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"I am other than Hyphenation.// I say, proudly, MY PEOPLE!/ I say, proudly, OUR PEOPLE!// Our People do not disdain to eat yams or melons or grits/ Or to put peanut butter in stew.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>-- And I'd like to interrupt myself here and say, as I've said many times, if you haven't tried that, try it, because it's absolutely delicious -- "I am Kojo. In West Africa Kojo/ Means Unconquerable.</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>My parents/ named me the seventh day from my birth/ in Black spirit, Black faith, Black communion./ I am Kojo. I am A Black./ And I Capitalize my name.// Do not call me out of my name."</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>I know I'm not gonna make any converts. And I know that African American sounds soft and sweet, and inoffensive: African American, as opposed to Black!</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Well at least you're tolerating me. I'm going to read to you a poem that begins my book Winnie and of course Winnie is Winnie Mandela. The opening poem: "Winnie Mandela, she/ the non-fiction</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>statement, the flight into resolving/ fiction,/ vivid over the landscape, a sumptuous sun/ for our warming, ointment at the gap of our wounding,/ sometimes/ would like to be a little girl again.//</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Skipping down a country road, singing.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Or a young woman, flirting,/ No cares beyond curl-braids and paint/ and effecting no change, no swerve, no jangle.// But Winnie Mandela, she,/ the She of our vision, the Code,/ the articulate</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>rehearsal, the founding mother, shall/ direct our choir of makers and wide music.//</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Think of plants and beautiful weeds in the Wilderness./ They can't do a thing about it (they are told)/ when trash is dumped at their roots./ Have no doubt they're indignant and daunted./ It is not</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>what they wanted.// Winnie Mandela, she/ is there to be vivid: there/ to assemble, to conduct the old magic,/ the frightened beauty, that trapped wild loveliness, the/ crippled reach,/ interrupted</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>order, the stalled clarity.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Listen, my Sisters, Brothers, all ye/ that dance on the brink of Blackness,/ never falling in:// Your vision your Code your Winnie is woman grown.// I Nelson the Mandela tell you so." [[00:38:24 | 00:38:25 | Laughter]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>I meant to tell you when I started reading it, that there was a surprise at the end. This was Nelson talking all the time, and isn't that just like a man to say "I, Nelson, the Mandela, tell you so."</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>Of course that was written before he was released from prison. I have here Winnie considering herself poet. And those of you who have seen her documentaries or seen her interviewed on TV, I think will</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>agree that this woman was definitely an essential poet.</font>
So I make her say, "Yet I know/ that I am Poet!/ I pass you my Poem.// A poem doesn't do everything for you./ You are supposed to go on with your thinking./ You are supposed to enrich/ the
other person's poem with your extensions,/ your uniquely personal understandings,/ thus making the poem serve you.//"

<font color='darkgreen'>"I pass you my Poem! — to tell you/ we are all vulnerable —/ the midget, the Mighty,/ the richest, the poor./ Men, women, children, and trees./ I am vulnerable./ Hector Peterson was vulnerable.// My</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>poem is life, and not finished./ It shall never be finished./ My Poem is life, and can grow.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Wherever life can grow, it will./ It will sprout out,/ and do the best it can./ I give you what I have./ You don't get all your questions answered in this world./ How many answers shall be found in</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>the developing world of my Poem?/ I don't know. Nevertheless, I put my Poem,/ which is my life, into your hands, where it will do the best it can.//"</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"I am not a tight-faced Poet.// I am tired of little tight-faced poets sitting down to/ shape perfect unimportant pieces./ Poems that cough lightly — catch back a sneeze./ This is the time for Big</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>Poems,/ roaring up out of sleaze,/ poems from ice, from vomit, and from tainted blood./ This is the time for a stiff or viscous poems./ Big, and Big"</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>But of course you know, a little Haiku -- three lines, five syllables, seven syllables, five syllables -- can be a big poem.</font>
Thank you. I'm gonna try to get this out to you. And Old Black Woman, Homeless and Indistinct. Now I know that if you haven't seen any homeless in the raw, you have certainly seen them on TV.

<font color='darkgreen'>Sometimes I go to little towns, and I don't see any homeless at all. There's no problem seeing them in New York, and Chicago, and Philadelphia. As soon as you hit the town, you see them. But when I go</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>to these scrubbed little towns, I say where are your homeless? Where do you keep them? Because I know they're there.   [[00:41:39 | 00:41:40 | Page Turns]] [[00:42:01 | 00:42:02 | Cough]]</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"Your every day is a pilgrimage, a blue hubbub, your days are collected bacchanals of fear and self troubling. And your nights, your nights when you put you down an alley or cardboard or viaduct. Your</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>lovers are rats, finding your secret places."</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"When you rise at another morning, you hit the street, your incessant enemy. See? Here you are in the so-busy world. You walk, you walk you pass the people, no, the people pass you. Here's a rich girl</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>marching briskly to her charms. She is suede and scarf and belting and perfume. She sees you not she sees you very well."</font>

<font color='darkgreen'>"At five in the afternoon Miss Rich-girl will go home to brooms and vacuum cleaners and carpeting, two cats, two marble-top tables, two telephones. Shiny green peppers, flowers in impudent vases,</font>
<font color='darkgreen'>visitors. Before all that there's luncheon to be known. Lasagna, lobster salad, sandwiches. All day there's coffee to be loved."</font>
